docs.title: What is mkdocs-nbsync?
docs.text:
mkdocs-nbsync is an innovative MkDocs plugin that treats Jupyter notebooks, Python scripts, and Markdown files as first-class citizens for documentation. Unlike traditional approaches, mkdocs-nbsync provides equal capabilities across all file formats, enabling seamless integration and dynamic execution with real-time synchronization.

It solves common challenges faced by data scientists, researchers, and technical writers:

  • Development happens in notebooks - ideal for experimentation and visualization
  • Documentation lives in markdown - perfect for narrative and explanation
  • Code resides in Python files - organized and version-controlled
  • Traditional integration is challenging - screenshots break, exports get outdated

docs.title: Inspiration & Comparison
docs.text:
mkdocs-nbsync was inspired by and builds upon the excellent work of two MkDocs plugins:

  • markdown-exec - Provides utilities to execute code blocks in Markdown files
  • mkdocs-jupyter - Enables embedding Jupyter notebooks in MkDocs

While these plugins offer great functionality, mkdocs-nbsync takes a unified approach by:

  1. Equal treatment - Unlike other solutions that prioritize one format, mkdocs-nbsync treats Jupyter notebooks, Python scripts, and Markdown files equally as first-class citizens
  2. Real-time synchronization - Changes to source files are immediately reflected in documentation
  3. Seamless integration - Consistent syntax across all file formats allows for flexible documentation workflows
  4. Image syntax code execution - Unique ability to execute code and embed visualizations anywhere Markdown image syntax (![alt](url)) is valid, including tables, lists, and complex layouts

docs.title: Acknowledgements
docs.text: The development of mkdocs-nbsync would not have been possible without the groundwork laid by markdown-exec and mkdocs-jupyter. We extend our sincere gratitude to the developers of these projects for their innovative contributions to the documentation ecosystem.

docs.title: Notebooks from Markdown
docs.text:
Extend standard markdown syntax to define notebook cells within your documentation. Present code and its output results concisely with tabbed display.

MarkdownRendered 
```python .md#plot
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(2, 1))
ax.plot([1, 3, 3, 4])
```

![Plot result](){#plot source="above"}

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(2, 1))
ax.plot([1, 3, 3, 4])

docs.title: Python File Integration
docs.text:
Directly reference external Python files and reuse defined functions or classes. Avoid code duplication and improve maintainability.

plot.py
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np


def plot(func):
    x = np.linspace(0, 360)
    y = func(np.radians(x))
    fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(2, 1))
    ax.plot(x, y)
    ax.set_title(f"Plot {func.__name__}")


if __name__ == "__main__":
    # %% #sqrt
    plot(np.sqrt)
MarkdownRendered 
![Plot result](plot.py){#sqrt source="on"}

plot(np.sqrt)

docs.title: Code Execution in Images
docs.text:
Execute Python code directly within image notation and display the results. This enables easy placement of dynamic visualizations in tables or complex layouts.

MarkdownRendered 
|         Sine          |        Cosine         |
| :-------------------: | :-------------------: |
| ![](){`plot(np.sin)`} | ![](){`plot(np.cos)`} |
Sine Cosine

docs.title: Code Execution with markdown-exec Style Syntax
docs.text:
mkdocs-nbsync supports the markdown-exec style code blocks with the exec="1" attribute as a compatible approach to code execution. While this syntax is familiar to markdown-exec users, mkdocs-nbsync executes it through the Jupyter Notebook engine instead, providing the ability to render diverse MIME content types (HTML, SVG, images, etc.) directly in your documentation. This enables richer and more complex outputs than traditional execution methods.

MarkdownRendered 
```python exec="1" source="tabbed-left"
import numpy as np
from PIL import Image
x = np.random.randint(0, 255, (50, 200), dtype=np.uint8)
Image.fromarray(x)
```
SourceResult 
import numpy as np
from PIL import Image
x = np.random.randint(0, 255, (50, 200), dtype=np.uint8)
Image.fromarray(x)

docs.title: Dynamic Updates and Execution
docs.text: Automatic synchronization between notebooks and documentation ensures code changes are reflected in real-time. View changes instantly in MkDocs serve mode.

docs.title: Getting Started
docs.text:
Follow these steps to get started with mkdocs-nbsync:

  1. Installation
  2. Configuration
  3. First Steps

docs.title: Configuration
docs.text: Configuring mkdocs-nbsync for your MkDocs site is simple but powerful, allowing you to customize how notebooks and Python files are integrated with your documentation.

docs.title: Basic Configuration
docs.text:
To use mkdocs-nbsync with MkDocs, add it to your mkdocs.yml file:

plugins:
  - search
  - mkdocs-nbsync

This minimal configuration uses all the default settings.

docs.title: Source Directory Configuration
docs.text:
Specify where mkdocs-nbsync should look for notebooks and Python files:

plugins:
  - search
  - mkdocs-nbsync:
      src_dir:
        - ../notebooks # Path to notebooks directory
        - ../scripts # Path to Python scripts

The src_dir option can be:

  • A single path as a string
  • A list of paths
  • Relative to your docs directory

docs.title: First Steps
docs.text: Let's walk through a quick example of using mkdocs-nbsync to integrate notebooks with your MkDocs documentation.

docs.title: Setting Up Your Project
docs.text:
Start with a typical MkDocs project structure:

my-project/
├── docs/
│   ├── index.md
│   └── ...
├── notebooks/
│   ├── analysis.ipynb
│   └── ...
├── scripts/
│   ├── plotting.py
│   └── ...
└── mkdocs.yml

docs.title: Configure MkDocs
docs.text:
Update your mkdocs.yml to include mkdocs-nbsync:

site_name: My Documentation
theme:
    name: material

plugins:
    - search
    - mkdocs-nbsync:
          src_dir:
              - ../notebooks
              - ../scripts

docs.title: 1. Prepare a Jupyter Notebook
docs.text:
Create or use an existing notebook with visualizations. Tag cells you want to reference with a comment:

# #simple-plot
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np
from matplotlib_inline.backend_inline import set_matplotlib_formats

set_matplotlib_formats("svg")

x = np.linspace(0, 10, 100)
plt.figure(figsize=(3, 1.5))
plt.plot(x, np.sin(x))
plt.title("Simple Sine Wave")

docs.title: 2. Reference in Your Documentation
docs.text:
In one of your markdown files (e.g., docs/index.md), add:

# My Project Documentation

Here's a visualization from our analysis:

![Sine wave plot](analysis.ipynb){#simple-plot}

docs.title: 3. Create a Python Script
docs.text:
Create a file scripts/plotting.py with visualization functions:

scripts/plotting.py
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np


def plot_sine(frequency=1):
    """Plot a sine wave with given frequency."""
    x = np.linspace(0, 10, 100)
    plt.figure(figsize=(2, 1.2))
    plt.plot(x, np.sin(frequency * x))
    plt.title(f"Sine Wave (f={frequency})")
    plt.ylim(-1.2, 1.2)


def plot_histogram(bins=20):
    """Plot a histogram of random data."""
    data = np.random.randn(1000)
    plt.figure(figsize=(2, 1.2))
    plt.hist(data, bins=bins)
    plt.title(f"Histogram (bins={bins})")

docs.title: 4. Use Functions in Your Documentation
docs.text:
Create a new file docs/examples.md:

# Examples

Let's demonstrate different plots:

![](plotting.py){#.}

## Sine Waves

|     Frequency = 1     |     Frequency = 2     |
| :-------------------: | :-------------------: |
| ![](){`plot_sine(1)`} | ![](){`plot_sine(2)`} |

## Histogram Examples

|           20 Bins           |           50 Bins           |
| :-------------------------: | :-------------------------: |
| ![](){`plot_histogram(20)`} | ![](){`plot_histogram(50)`} |
Frequency = 1 Frequency = 2 20 Bins 50 Bins

docs.title: 5. Create a Markdown-Based Notebook
docs.text:
Create a file docs/custom.md:

# Custom Analysis

Here's an analysis created directly in markdown:

```python .md#_
import numpy as np
import pandas as pd

# Generate sample data
data = pd.DataFrame({
    'x': np.random.randn(100),
    'y': np.random.randn(100),
    'group': np.random.choice(['A', 'B', 'C'], 100)
})
```

```python .md#scatter
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import seaborn as sns
from matplotlib_inline.backend_inline import set_matplotlib_formats

set_matplotlib_formats("svg")

plt.figure(figsize=(3, 2))
sns.scatterplot(data=data, x='x', y='y', hue='group')
plt.title('Scatter Plot by Group')
```

![Scatter plot](.md){#scatter}

You can also use the exec attribute to execute the code and display the result:

```python exec="1"
fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(3, 2))
ax.plot([1, 3, 2])
```

docs.title: 7. Run Your Documentation
docs.text:
Start the MkDocs development server:

mkdocs serve --open

docs.title: Common Issues
docs.text:
1. Images Not Showing:

    • Check paths in your configuration
    • Ensure notebooks have correctly tagged cells
    • Verify Python dependencies are installed

  2. Execution Errors:

    • Check the console output for error messages
    • Ensure your environment has all required packages

  3. Changes Not Reflecting:

    • Hard refresh your browser
    • Restart the MkDocs server
    • Check file paths and identifiers

docs.title: Installation
docs.text: Installing mkdocs-nbsync is straightforward and can be done using uv or pip, the Python package manager.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
Before installing nbsync, ensure you have the following:

  • Python 3.10 or higher
  • uv or pip (Python package manager)
  • MkDocs 1.6 or higher (documentation generator)

docs.title: Basic Installation
docs.text:
Install mkdocs-nbsync using uv or pip:

uv pip install mkdocs-nbsync
# or
pip install mkdocs-nbsync

This command installs the latest stable version of mkdocs-nbsync and its core dependencies.

docs.title: Installation of nbconvert
docs.text:
For dynamic execution functionality, install nbconvert:

uv pip install nbconvert
# or
pip install nbconvert
